questions.title: Networks & Game Theory
questions.content:
• 1/18 [Networks primer]
    D. Easley and J. Kleinberg. Networks, Crowds, and Markets: Reasoning About a Highly Connected World.

questions.title: Mechanism Design
questions.content:
• 2/01 [Mechanism design intro 1]
    Roughgarden, T. (2016). Twenty lectures on algorithmic game theory.

questions.title: Individual decision making
questions.content:
• 2/08 [Behavioral economics]
    D. Kahneman. A perspective on judgment and choice: Mapping bounded rationality.
  • 2/13 [Bounded rationality]
    Aumann, R. J. (1997). Rationality and bounded rationality.
  • 2/15 [Decision making & Scarcity]
    A. K. Shah, E. Shafir, and S. Mullainathan. Scarcity frames value.
  • 2/20 [Complexity and rationality]
    Papadimitriou, C. H. and Yannakakis, M. (1994). On complexity as bounded rationality (extended abstract).

questions.title: Social choice (voting)
questions.content:
• 2/27 [Quadratic voting]
    Lalley, S. P. and Weyl, E. G. (2018). Quadratic voting: How mechanism design can radicalize democracy.
  • 3/01 [Knapsack voting]
    Goel, A., Krishnaswamy, A. K., Sakshuwong, S., and Aitamurto, T. (2015). Knapsack voting.
    Goel, A., Krishnaswamy, A.K. and Sakshuwong, S., 2016. Budget aggregation via knapsack voting: welfare-maximization and strategy-proofness.
  • 3/06 [Participatory budgeting, fairness]
    Fain, B., Munagala, K., and Shah, N. (2018). Fair allocation of indivisible public goods.

questions.title: Social signals
questions.content:
• 3/08 [Badges 1]
    Anderson, A., Huttenlocher, D., Kleinberg, J., and Leskovec, J. (2013). Steering user behavior with badges.
  • 3/13 [Foregrounding social norms]
    Goldstein, N. J., Cialdini, R. B., and Griskevicius, V. (2008). A room with a viewpoint: Using social norms to motivate environmental conservation in hotels.
  • 3/15 [Badges 2]
    D. Easley and A. Ghosh. Incentives, gamification, and game theory: An economic approach to badge design.

questions.title: Broader ideas from algorithmic game theory
questions.content:
• 3/27 [The Price of Anarchy (what if there were no mechanisms?)]
    Roughgarden, T. (2016). Selfish Routing and the Price of Anarchy, Twenty lectures on algorithmic game theory.

questions.title: Macroscopic behavior in a network
questions.content:
• 3/29 [Behavior and network structure]
    Granovetter, M. (1985). Economic action and social structure: The problem of embeddedness.
  • 4/03 [Diffusion of behavior in a network]
    N. Immorlica, J. Kleinberg, M. Mahdian, and T. Wexler. The role of compatibility in the diffusion of technologies through social networks.
  • 4/05 [Collective action]
    Chwe, M. (1999). Structure and Strategy in Collective Action.

questions.title: Policy
questions.content:
• 4/10 [Choice architecture, nudges]
    R. H. Thaler, C. R. Sunstein, and J. P. Balz. Choice architecture.
  • 4/12 [The challenge of fairness in CS]
    Selbst, A. D., Boyd, D., Friedler, S. A., Venkatasubramanian, S., and Vertesi, J. (2019). Fairness and abstraction in sociotechnical systems.
